title: 111_hr1956
content: The Act is titled the "Crime Victim Restitution and Court Fee Intercept Act" and allows for the offset of state judicial debts against income tax refunds. The "Crime Victim Restitution and Court Fee Intercept Act" amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow for the collection of past-due state judicial debts by reducing overpayments payable to individuals and paying the amount to the state judicial branch or agency. The Act allows for the collection of past-due state judicial debts by reducing overpayments and paying the amount to the state judicial branch or agency. The person making the overpayment is notified of the reduction and the names, taxpayer identification numbers, and addresses of joint filers are included in the notice. The reduction of overpayments is done after any liability for internal revenue tax is addressed. The overpayment shall be reduced for various liabilities including internal revenue tax, past-due support, debts to Federal agencies, State income tax obligations, and covered unemployment compensation debt before being credited to future tax liabilities. If the Secretary receives notice from State agencies. The overpayment by a person will be credited towards debts owed to State agencies or State judicial branches in the order they accrued. Rules similar to subsection (e)(4) will apply for debts under this subsection. A past-due, legally enforceable State judicial debt is defined as a debt resulting from a court judgment or sentence. State judicial debt refers to debts resulting from court judgments or sentences in criminal or traffic cases in the State, including court costs, fees, fines, assessments, and restitution to crime victims. The Secretary will issue regulations regarding these debts. The Secretary will issue regulations prescribing the submission of notices for past-due State judicial debts, specifying types of debts and minimum amounts eligible for reduction. State agencies may be required to pay a fee for this procedure. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 requires states to promptly reimburse any erroneous payments made to them by the Secretary. Additionally, there are amendments regarding the disclosure of return information to agencies requesting reductions under specific sections. Conforming amendments are also made to section 6402(a) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include subsections (f) and (g) in various sections, such as 6402(a), 6402(d), and 6402(e). These changes involve reducing overpayments for State judicial debts and future federal tax liabilities. Subsection 6402(f) is also amended to include provisions for reducing overpayments. The amendments made to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 involve reducing overpayments for State judicial debts and future federal tax liabilities. The changes include provisions for reducing overpayments and apply to refunds for taxable years starting after December 31, 2008.
